Wonderful art Museum. beautiful art, art demonstrations on the day we were visiting - it was very interesting and beautiful gardens

Colorful Compund. Colorful Tradition.. This museum is a part of a lovely compund. Lotus pond, cafe (didn't try), and multiple buildings with traditional Balinese art, carvings, and sculptures. Very picturesque. Even if looking at art isn't your cup of tea, the grounds make for great photos which you can take at total leisure. It's only 50,000rp. Not even $5, so it's not expensive, and worth a visit when in bustling ubud.

Lovely compound. A very nice walk around the grounds and a great look at Balinese art from around 1850 until today, most paintings have some description advising what you can see. A cup of tea at the care is included in the entry price.

Expensive. Expensive entry fee not justified. Traditional paintings are dark and fraught with symbols, require a little effort to understand, but good explanations are provided in English. We would have enjoyed more modern style paintings and sculptures.

Mostly traditional Balinese art. The garden setting is beautiful, and the various exhibits are well-displayed in the different buildings. As well as the traditional Balinese art featuring many a visual interpretation of Hindu lore, there are some amazingly old tapestries and some excellent carvings that would look great in my living room! If you don't feel like trekking very far from the very main tourist centre of town, this is the art museum for you.

Feast on the art but skip the meal. Our family of four visited the museum mid-morning, purchasing the tickets that included a meal, thinking that it would provide a good break for the kids between touring the various pavilions. That wasn't such a bad plan and may work for you, but the portions were small and not as filling as other warungs or restaurants we visited and so didn't tide the children over for the 'second half' as well as we had hoped. Presentation was excellent, though. My son marveled at the intricately carved watermelon garnish on his delicious watermelon juice, and both children devoured with their eyes and mouths the ornately displayed desserts. No surprise there.The art, housed in several buildings among peaceful gardens, is top notch (based on other museums we visited) and provides a good introduction (with some helpful explanation in English) to Balinese painting and wood carving, accompanied by the calming sounds of a single bamboo gamelan outside during our visit. As complete neophytes, we learned about the influence of Westerners such as Rudolf Bonnet and Walter Spies in the 1930s bringing Balinese painting into the modern era with the portrayal of scenes from daily life rather than religious themes and metaphors as before. We also saw why I Gusti Nyoman Lempad is so celebrated -- his finely detailed works are a cut above the rest -- along with Ida Bagus Made who seemed to be a renaissance man, creating art in all kinds of media.With a little effort, it is possible for the kids to get something out of the experience too. The grounds are great for wandering and provide a needed break between pavilions, but our 5 year old was captivated by the wood carvings and enjoyed identifying the various animals portrayed. He was pleased as punch when he later saw his proclaimed "favorite carving" prominently displayed on the cover of one of reference books in the small museum shop. Our eleven year old was interested in learning about the organic materials from which the traditional natural palate of Balinese colors are obtained and then trying to find the colors in the paintings, with yellow a challenge in the older paintings but white (made from crushed pig bones which was a gross-out in itself) still prominent. From the reviews, it seems that some people are evaluating the museum not on the quality of the works but on their views of the genres. For example, personally, I don't care much for the young artist school, but it is what it is. If you like the vibrancy and naivete, then you will enjoy the many examples housed in one of the pavilions. At the other extreme, the Batuan school paintings are dark but the detail is incredible. If you visit only one museum in Ubud, this should be it. A great overview and top-notch art.The museum also offers workshops in various cultural arts including gamelan, various types of painting, batik, woodcarving, shadow puppet carving, dance, offerings and more. The options overlap but Puri Lukisan seems to offer longer workshops and a greater variety of choices than those offered by the Pondok Pekak Library. On equivalent workshops offered by both, the library tends to be cheaper, and their shorter but much cheaper workshops on some arts might be more appropriate for children or those just wanting to get a taste for an hour instead of making a half day investment of their time, so if you are interested in workshops, check out both before deciding.

What a gem!. The grounds are beautiful and I thought the art was incredibly interesting. The paintings portray Hindu and Muslim myths and are rendered with beautiful detail and colour. A feast for the eyes and the brain.

Art reveals much of Balinese life-view. Take even a surgery turn through the Lukisan museum and you get a good sense of traditional arts and the life view that is teeming with gods, barongs, rangdas, spirits. Mythological histories are retold again and again. Paintings are densely populated and stylistically similar; in Bali tradition is everything. Though perhaps not to your taste, the overview gives dimension to your visit to bring you to some measure of understanding of culture.

Very interesting artwork in beautiful grounds. Great to see and understand Balinese art more, most pictures tell very interesting stories. Grounds are lovely, peaceful and well kept, free drink with your ticket too.
Beautiful Balinese Artwork. Spent a few hours here enjoying the balinese artwork. Highly recommended. The exhibit with the minature painting was especially enjoyable.

Good to see Balinese Art. This is a palace turned into a museum. The setting was really beautiful, as you walked from building to building you were walking through a calm and well taken care of yard/garden. It was really interesting to see Balinese art and I really enjoyed my time there. There is a cafe inside the museum as well. You can purchase a ticket that includes just a drink or a ticket that includes lunch.

Great place to visit for Balinese culture and art. Great place to visit if you wish to understand more about the Balinese culture. Art pieces were beautiful and most depict beliefs and stories of the Hinduism religion (which is very significant in Balinese culture). Be sure to allocate about 2 - 2.5 hours for the visit for a good understanding of the culture and other attractions and performances (eg. Kecak dance) will all make sense. Each ticket purchased comes with either a complimentary lunch or tea, which is a plus.

Peace and quiet in central Ubud. I knew little about Balinese art and this museum shows its development via a solid collection of paintings. The art is displayed in several buildings that surround a beautiful garden. Absolutely worth a visit.

A lovely piece of serenity.... I love this museum for being so central in Ubud, so pleasant in ambience. We left the busy buzzling road behind us which is just a door step away. A complimentary entrance for children is a bonus, a hidden invitation for the unlikely coming younger age visitors. Their selection of paintings were mainly pre-war selections. They are not just a painting gallery, but more of a history of culture and are filled heavily with traditional believe and stories. Almost each piece presented a Hindu epic which is the soul of Balinese arts. It was so beautiful and engaging experience.The ground: an effortless piece of Ubud.

A bit of culture in the middle of Ubud. Take a visit when you are feeling a bit tired after trekking the streets of Central Ubud. The historical art works are fascinating, and teaches you a little about the history of Indonesia and Bali.The gardens are beautiful - take a leisurely stroll through and enjoy the calm surroundings

Great collection of paintings. Gives you a snapshot in the art history of Bali and the developments throughout the years, especially paintings. The style was not our thing and not all of the paintings have explanations in English. But if you like art it is a place you must visit.

Amazing. It was like time travel experience. So many Balinese art masterpiece are here. Some of them are from 16th century. Some are so mystical. Great works from maestro. The display is quite informative. A must to visit in Ubud.
Great art display. The balinese art on display was fabulous - showed great history and also had some modern artists for sale - really enjoyed this museum.

Educational Experience. Through the paintings and sculptures, I got a pretty good idea of the history of Bali. The colors, the theme were exquisite! Loved the music from a simple wooden xylophone a gentleman played outside one of the halls. And the finishing touch, tea on the veranda. That was very classy. A wonderful afternoon experience to come in from the rain.

Great Overview of Balinese painting. It had a lot of very detailed paintings and drawings by some of Bali's talented artists such as Lempad - who was a great cartoonist as well, and very innovative for the time, as well as other artists, influenced by Walter Spies. Well laid out

The best museum experience. The grounds were as much a part of the experience as the art itself. It was very refreshing to see traditional detailed paintings that had hidden satires painted in them. The museum spans a few buildings across the gardens. I could not believe the size of the koi fishes in their pools. OMG.

Lovely Palace garden and stone sculptures of Gods.. Disappointing as walk around gardens was very restricted because the Royal Family was still residing there. Also souvenit cards quite few to chose from.

Linda Vall loves painting. This museum is slap bang in the middle of Ubud and is great for a visit around a couple of hours to see it. The art works are typically
Balinese, you will love them. There is a gallery with more recent
Art which is for sale and very reasonably priced.

Great place for a Gamelan class. Taking a gamelan class was a priority for our family while visiting Bali. We had a great experience with our class at this museum. The instructor was so friendly and patient. He had an amazing smile, and really took time with us. They also brought us cake and a cold drink during our hour class. The class was private -- just for our family of four. They accomodated our schedule and fit us in when it was convenient for us. Afterwards, we wandered around the beautiful grounds and enjoyed seeing the art in all of the buildings. Make sure to confirm that with the price of your ticket you get a cup of coffee or tea in the nice cafe.

Beautiful museum capturing Bali's rich artistic cultural heritage. The Puri Lukisan Museum is a beautiful museum. It features three exhibits in different buildings. The museum contains mainly traditional style paintings that reflect the Balinese culture and worldview. The surroundings are very beautiful as well. I could spend all day here looking at paintings, having coffee with friends, and just walking along the beautiful museum grounds.

Good to understand the development of Balinese paintings..... The museum is about 100 m from the market or the palace of King of Ubud. It has a spaciousparking lot, something rare in the vicinity of Ubud town center. The area has 4 buildngs for displaying Balinese paintings from different eras, most notably the era after 1930s where influences of western painters who lived in Bali at that time, are visible such as the use of colors, shading, materials and themes.There is also a Marketing 3.0 museum but it was closed during our visit.Some of the paintings probably need to be stored in some protecting enclosure. I was afraid of people, despite the signs, touching the surface of the paintings. I am also not sure about the humidity or sunshine controls. I personally like the traditional miniature paintings by artists from Keliki village. These were fine, detailed pictures of humans, animals, trees, gods, demons and so on with intricate layering of shading which makes the paintings appear to be in 3D. I actually need a magnifying glass to see some paintings as these were no more larger than A4 paper size.The area is so serene that you can use as a getaway or cooling down site after visiting the market or the Puri which tends to be crowded I the afternoon. The museum closes at 6 pm but the nearby cafe may still open until later.

Worth a visit. This art museum was worth a visit. It is conveniently located and easily able to be taken in over an hour or two. The grounds are also lovely. It gave a nice sense of the development of local art.

Cultural Awareness. This museum/art gallery provides exactly what the guidebooks say and that is the opportunity to see Balinese culture presented through some pretty amazing pieces of art and sculpture. If you any interest in other cultures then this stop is highly recommended during your central Bali tour. Check out the garden scultpure enveloped by the ficus tree and enjoy the peace and quiet while having your tea or coffee.
Good. I'd say Neka was much better, but it's conveniet and they also have a good collection of woodcarvings and have various classes. The painting class was very good indeed.

Overrated. I'm fairly interested in art and always try to visit local art museums whenever I'm traveling. However, I found this museum a bit boring. I felt like I was seeing the same painting over and over again and the whole thing took me under 20 minutes to get through. To be fair, I have no knowledge of Balinese art. Still, I have no idea why this place was so highly recommended in all the guide books. The service was quite good though.

A delightful place. Such lovely grounds enhance any other experience you might want to pursue here. I visited on a week day a little before noon and purchased a combined ticket which included lunch.That was a good value as well as a relaxing way to dine simply. Plus it broke up the walking. Saw someone else was taking dance lessons. The exhibits themselves were quite good, but the museum and grounds were more than that. For example, a man was playing bamboo gamelan that you could hear as you walked around. "Very Ubud" would probably be a fair statement. This place was much to my liking.

Wood carving Workshop - unique and awesome!. Today i made the Wood carving Workshop at the Museum for 450000 Rupiah! It Run from 10 to 5 o'clock, including Snack, Drink and a delicous lunch. The Money was spent well Though. I can definitely recommend the Workshop. It was a Lot of Fun and nice creative work with a good teacher ständig by your side.

Hitory with culture. Here you go to the history making of UBUD culture. Old painting by old balinese masters depicting the life style of ubudians and the religious hirory of bali. You find pictures of furst europianns who created part of the recent culture of ubud by mixing with, teaching art and loving people of ubud.

Awesome, quick "modern" art museum. Really cool museum for a quick 1-2 hour view. That's about my limit for a museum, anyway. While billed as modern art, its not what I would normally think of, i.e., at no point did I think to myself "gee, I could do that myself". Its kind of modern interpretations of Balinese traditional art, with a standout for me Ida Bagus Made. The richness of the colors wasn't something you commonly see...the paint used in many paintings is (apparently) a concotion of earth, bone, and other ingredients.The grounds were relatively compact, and beautiful. Any landscape architects in particular would really appreciate them.Only suggestion would be to spruce up the gift should....poss. a big revenue source for museum, as I was looking to take a moment of the art for our own home.

Best art I have ever seen. The art here makes you realise why Ubud is so famous worldwide for its art. The pictures here tell a story really well and you get sucked into all the intricate designs within them. Definitely worth a visit.

Museum with a Mission. Unub is the heart of Balinese art. A joint effort by the Ubud princely family and a Dutch artist over was made to preserve and promote traditional art. Over a few decades, despite war, occupation, revolution, deposition, and at least one apathetic philistine in a position to throw a spanner in the works, Puri Lukisan--the Palace of Painting--was created to celebrate the incredible traditional arts of Bali. A wide range of painting techniques is employed, from painting on paper and canvas to painting on cloth, and sculpture. Many of the works are "busy" in the sense that Dutch and Italian cityscapes are busy: the painting are packed full of incredible detail so the longer you look at one the more you see. Wonderful stuff, and a tribute to both the visionary and persistent men who created the museum, and the artists whose works are displayed in the galleries. I am attaching a few examples of the art here.Side notes; (1) through June 28, there is a special exhibit of the works of the Keliki miniaturists. Miniaturists suggests postcard sized paintings, but here really refers to the small scale of the paintings, the better to pack more details in. Keliki is a small village near Ubud with a very high percentage of local artists: about 20% of the villagers are artists with the techniques being handed down from father to son. (2) for folks staying in the southern beach resorts, note that the convenient Nura Nura bus system does run busses up to Ubud, for 70 K each way. I've been on that road half a dozen times, and the run can take two hours due to traffic. An air-conditioned small bus is a great way to get up to Ubud, even if the promised wifi doesn't work, and the bus's second stop is right at this museum.

Nice setting in Central Ubud.. Nice museum in Central Ubud showcasing different schools of Balinese arts. When I visited they were showing how traditional weaving and wood carving is done, which was really impressive. But at the end of the day, the attraction is the art on display.
Loved it. Beautiful Art Gallery. Amazing collections. Great to do on a rainy day. Admission price includes Tea/Coffee and 2 delicious cakes. Highly recommend!

Well worth a visit. Gorgeous grounds with gorgeous art. Spent approx. 3.5 hours here, though that was with a leisurely meal at the onsite restaurant. Without the meal can be done in less than 3 hours, even with lingering over the displays. Detailed descriptions of displays, including sequences of religious painting depicting several important religious tales. Also has a traditional musician playing outside one of the buildings, which added to the ambiance.

Beautiful museum in garden layout. Wanting to experience and explore some of the culture of Ubud we headed into the museum to spend the morning. Had an amazing couple of hours getting up close and admiring the traditional artworks and paintings of this extensive Balinese collections across the various ages (each is in it's own separate building). The entrance fee of 75,000 included an afternoon refreshment. Well worth a visit while in Ubud even if to just relax and enjoy the peaceful gardens away from the hustle and bustle of the streets.

Beautiful!. This museum is amazing. The layout in the garden resembles the famous Balinese rice patties. There are three main buildings w art work featured. Every staff member was jovial and welcoming you inside to see the art work. Your entry fee (75,000 rupiah) includes a complimentary beverage at the small cafe. I ordered a sprite (well an extra given one was free) and the mushroom soup w blue cheese; delicious!! A really great intro to Balinese culture and Hindu faith. A short walk from my bungalow making it impossible to miss!!

Museum, art and more, central Ubud. We had walked past this place over the years thinking it was a temple. In fact it has spacious tiered gardens and an extensive collection of Balinese art from the 16th century till today. You will see donated works from Rudolph Bonnett and Walter spies, both instrumental in bringing Balinese art to a wider audience and in introducing Balinese artists to new mediums and styles. It's the oldest art museum in Ubud. It's quite extensive so we paused after an hour to have an iced tea and cake/dessert at the cafe. All included in the entrance fee of $7.50AU each. The history of the museum is also very interesting and features Tjokorda Gde Raka Sukawati, a contemporary of spies and Bonnett, and Ubud royal. Charismatic and engaging of world leaders and adventurous tourists in the 50's and beyond.A good way to while away a few hours in the cultural heart of Bali

Jaw dropping detail in art. Every artwork in they museum begs for at least 10-20 minutes, just to get a complete understanding of the art. I must say that I was tempted to pick up one or two. The prices were also reasonable. The best work in wood that caught my eye was an entwined Rama and Sita . The piece of wood's normal curvature and dents were taken into account and beautifully woven into the embraced couple. There is also a huge ficus tree with extensive roots that grab your attention. Do take out at least an hour to spend in this museum.

Balinese Art in a Tropical Setting. One of the best reasons to visit this museum is the grounds which are well-kept and includes a small open-air cafe. The art inside the museum is comprised mainly of paintings of local people and traditional culture with incredible detail that can keep you occupied for at least an hour or two.

Good museum. We went in with the mindset of traditional historical artefacts but this museum is more about art in bali over the past 100 or so years. So much more recent than expected but still good. Some of the art was quite graphic so be aware if you are taking children. While we were in ubud there was a royal wedding on so got to watch some of the local women getting their hair prepared at this site.
peaceful and thought provoking. set in lovely gardens showcasing Indonesian art, it was great to see it all, especially enjoyed pictures from the past of village life in Bali

Bukan hanya lukisan, tapi juga tentang Marketing 3.0!. Museum ini cukup menarik utk yang suka karya lukisan tradisional Bali. Museum terbagi menjadi beberapa gedung terpisah yang menyimpan berbagai koleksi lukisan, pahatan, serta batik berisi berbagai cerita/legenda dan sejarah rakyat Bali. Selain itu, ada juga bagian tersendiri yang berisi koleksi pribadi yang menceritakan sejarah Puri Ubud. Dan jika berkunjung ke museum ini, jangan lupa mampir ke Museum Marketing 3.0 (oleh Hermawan Kartajaya) yang juga ada dalam 1 area dan dapat dikunjungi secara gratis. Setelah puas melihat-lihat koleksi museum, lanjutkan dengan menikmati kolam teratai di halaman museum lalu rehat sejenak ditemani kopi & cake di cafetaria (Special note: walaupun free dgn menukarkan tiket masuk museum, kopi & cake di cafe ini seriously recommended! :)). P.S: Per Desember 2013, tiket masuk Puri Lukisan adalah IDR 75.000, sudah termasuk complimentary drink & snack di cafetaria dan juga kunjungan ke Museum of Marketing 3.0 di area yang sama.
Art, History, Culture and Artist. This museum is an insight into richness if Balinese art, artists and their work. Landscape is beautiful and amazing atmosphere.

Lovely place. Historical art. Manageable size. Gorgeous grounds. Sweet tea house. Easy walking distance from center of Ubud. Great way to spend a morning. Learn something about Balinese art from the past.

The House of Bali's Masterpieces Art. This museum is wonderful. If you're in to arts, here's the place you MUST visit. in this museum you'll find the finest Bali's painting work. This museum is also an ICON of UBUD.

Extraordinary museum for the best of Bali's painting and more. I've been going to Bali for the past 40 years and have known this museum from when it was just one building. Now with four exhibition spaces, three for the permanent collection and one for temporary shows, the Puri Lukisan has become the best programmed and most interesting museum in Bali. Visitors to Bali interested in art should come here early in their visit as all the arts of Bali will be more accessible after you've seen the best work of the past 100 years here.And, by the way, the museum cafe is one of the best (and quietest) restaurants in Ubud for lunch or dinner. An excellent kitchen, generous servings well presented, reasonably priced, overlooking a palace garden and lotus pond. It's open all day, so it's a good place to break a museum visit with a snack and a drink.

small and informative. This is a lovely little museum on the main road in Ubud, so it's easy to walk to (and nice to get some quiet!). It includes a variety of etchings, paintings, carvings, and tapestries that show a fundamental history of the area.

Interesting Balinese Paintwork !!. The Museum Puri Lukisan is the oldest art museum in Bali which has display of modern traditional Balinese paintings and wood carvings .Do not miss out to visit this interesting Painting Museum designed with Balinese Traditional architecture that is integrated with pure nature and atmosphere of Ubud Village.

A must.. You cannot visit Bali without understanding Balinese painting and its roots and meanings: this you will easily learn in this museum divided in thematic gallerries with explanations both in Indonesian and English. The admission ticket of IDR75.000 includes a free afternoon tea at the Museum restaurant, consisting in a cold or hot drink and a delicious slice of chocolate cake!!

OK if you are short of time but Neka and ARMA much better. This was the 4 the museum that I have visited in Ubud and the most disappointing. You cannot just pay for entry, you must pay for lunch or tea as well. There is not much explanation about the paintings and the rooms are rather dark which makes reading what there is difficult if you need glasses etc to read. Go to Necka or Arma instead.

Nice museum and make a mask. This is a wonderful museum. A lot of interesting displays. Also signed up for course to paint a mask for 300,000 Rp (~US$25).
And go to the Mask and Puppet Museum near Maas (short drive from Ubud). The museum is huge and free. It is excellent.

A trip down cultural lane. Wandered into Puri Lukisan on the spur of the moment as we walked past it. Entry includes a drink and some cake (which was yum!).Puri Lukisan was great. There was a lot of information on the history of the museum and the art scene in Ubud. The only downside was the fact that it was called a 'museum' when it's actually more so an art gallery. We were looking forward to seeing historical artifacts etc from the region, but instead the history is told in the paintings. You can also watch a couple of local artists do their thing. On the day we went we watched and spoke to a female weaver and a guy who did art on dried leaves using a blade and cooked nuts as the "ink".Well worth the trip in for those who are interested in this type of thing.

Worth it!. Beautiful paintings and sculptures. The artworks are housed in four buildings scattered in a big garden compound. Well worth the entrance fees of Rp 75 000. Ticket price include a refreshing drink and cakes at the restful cafe. Do allocate at least 2 hours to fully appreciate the place.

Impressive Museum. This museum is a must for everybody who is interested in Bali culture and I guess everyone who comes to Ubud, is - right?Besides, it is beautilly set against rice paddies in the back.Christophe

Oasis. This art museum in central Ubud is a calm oasis in the downtown. There're a lot of stairs to go into the four halls but you'll be rewarded with examples of Balinese art including one from the 17th century. Explanations are in English. Lovely water lily ponds adds to the serenity,

lovely quiet spot. some beautiful examples of Balinese painting, both traditional and modern. Shame the museum is not climate-controlled to be able to preserve them well over time. The beautiful gardens alone are worth seeing.

Fantastic. Get the early dinner package.. We were very surprised to find that this museum (which lonely planet listed as only 20,000 idr) was actually much more than that. You can buy a coffee, snack and entry for 75,000 idr, a lunch set menu for 110,000 idr or an early dinner where you can choose from any main for 125,000 idr. The museum itself is stunning, fantastic. We had never experienced Indonesian/Balinese art and it was wonderful. Then we had our meal and WOW. A fresh juice, a delicious main, dessert and delicious coffee. All for around 10 dollars US. Get there at about 4:00-4:30 for the early dinner special as the museum closes at 6, but the dinner is available later.

This museum gave us a impression of Indonesian Art, we never saw before.. This was my 1st time in a Indonesian museum of art and I was deeply impressed, by different styles of painting and woodencarving. Also the visiting of Queen Juliana of the Netherlands , Ethel and Robert Kennedy show me the importance of this museum. Great thanks to people who donated art to this museum. It was my plessure to be here.

Art by Traditional and Visiting Artists. The Puri Lukisan Museum is a wonderful collection of Balinese art, mostly of the modern period. The buildings and setting should be appreciated as well as the art.

Great Collection but Poor Experience. I believe that the museum has precious collection on historical Balinese painting distinguish style, and it is indeed. On the other hand the service is just average if not close to poor. There is no guide to explain us about the great collection. Visitors are just left wandering around without any clue. Unless you are a scholar on art study you will leave this museum empty handed for sure in despite of visiting treasure experience.

Amazing Balinese art. There are some truly remarkable pieces in the museum's collection, and I'm glad it's being collected and conserved. The entrance fee came with tea and cake which was a very nice touch! The grounds are beautiful too.

Traditional Balinese paintings. This is a spacious museum with four main buildings. The art is mainly typical Balinese paintings of local and Indian myths. Because of that it tends to be a bit repetitive and although there is a brief description of the story they somehow blend into one.
Nice Place. If you like painting art you must see this place. You will see the painting from year 1600. Now they add 1 building for marketing museum very inspiring.

Incredible paintings stun through one's soul!. We were amazed by the cleanliness of the museum grounds. The art collections are wonderful. The various types of artists are represented n paintings and carvings. This is not a huge museum and one can see all of it in less than two hours ... or one hour if you do not study the paintings as we do.

Relaxing and enjoyable. During our recent visit to Ubud, we spent time in several art museums, including the Puri Lukisan Musuem, ARMA and the quirky Blanco Museum. Of these, Puri Lukisan was the most interesting in terms of helping us to gain some understanding of Balinese art. It is a calm, relaxing place. It was also a very pleasant spot to have an enjoyable lunch, while listening to some music. Thoroughly recommended.
Neka Museum is Better. A collection of Balinese art right on the main street in the heart of Ubud, but the collection at the Neka Museum, which is private and outside the town, is better.

Wonderful art in a great setting. I enjoyed my visit and was happy I planned to stay long enough to saver every aspect of the art. There is also an outdoor restaurant which is very pleasant. My only little gripe is that it was hard to find the bathroom the first half hour. The staff were helpful and there is a kiosk to buy excellent art books. This is a must see if you are in the Ubud area.

Very enjoyable. The museum is very nicely done with an assortment o art and history of Bali. It was very easy to walk around and there is an assortment of art work and items to purchase. Well worth the IR75,000 entrance fee.

A HORIZON-EXPANDING VISIT. Its gorgeous (and well maintained) landscape made me felt as if I were in the heaven of lotus. A sizeable pond of blooming lotus with a stone sculpture of Lakshmi Goddess (wearing poleng sarong – typical Balinese B&W checkered fabric) in the middle of the pond had halted my steps to spend some quite moment there. I also saw a lot of little students attending a drawing class on an open space pavilion on the left. When I was there, Balinese style Wayang paintings by Ketut Madra (the master of wayang painter from Ubud) were exhibited. By chance, the curator, David Irons, who also wrote the exhibition catalogue was there and gave me a private guided tour. Thanks Mr. Irons, I did widen my knowledge, not only about Balinese paintings but also the Mahabharata and Ramayana characters. The other pavilion displays various beautiful Balinese paintings. Postcards and books of Balinese arts/paintings are available for sale at the entrance counter. What a great visit!

Great restaurant . Museum itself was an average but the restaurant was great. I purchased lunch combo ticket including a drink, main course, dessert and coffee. The dessert, fried banana with chocolate source and vanilla ice cream, was excellent.

Painting and offering making lessons!. We came as a class of 16 and we were able to have some hands on experience making and drawing some of the really traditional batuan paintings on a canvas and painting as well. We had some guides there to teach us on how to draw and paint. I drew a painting on Hanuman, an ancient deity of the Hindu Ramayana Epics. There were 3 guides to help us out and also i took around 2 hour to complete my drawing and time passed so fast cause the environment there was just amazing for doing the arts.Its cooling, spacious and filled with greens and it really takes your mind of almost everything. There is toilet facilities, a cafe nearby. The day was lovely, with just the right amount of sun, without it being too scorched. Tourists that passed by were just awed at what we were doing. Im really glad that I visited this place and the second day, we came we made offerings, simple ones that you would normally see on the sides of the roads in Ubud. It's really a touch of how living in Bali would be like. And I can say it's a slow and satisfied way of living!

Kept our kids entertained for a few hours. This museum has been extended fairly recently and gone up in price - the cheapest ticket is 75,000 including coffee and cake, we went for the set lunch for 115,000 which included a juice/soft drink, main course, dessert and coffee and the food and service were good. Their was a torrential downpour so we got stuck here for 3 hours and our 3 kids stayed entertained watching an artist and exploring the rooms including the new educational facility. Overall a good way to spend a few hours and learn more about the artistic history of the area.

for art lovers. as someone who is no art expert but love observing the aesthetics of things, i enjoyed my visit as i was able to see the different balinese art styles and how they manifested in works that might be on similar subjects, yet bring out different things based on the art style.the ticket allows you to claim a juice/coffee/tea at the end of the visit at the museum cafe, which also sells a selection of mains/desserts. not the cheapest place (I had the burger which came with fries & salad for 50, 000 IDR) but its okay food when you're famish and its raining cats & dogs. its open-air though so the flies can be quite bothersome if you want to have a slow meal.set aside at least 1.5hrs to browse through the collections in detail.

Best Museum of All. Three buildings full of Bali paintings. Beautiful grounds. A delicious lunch (I chose the entrance/lunch combo package). Building One was my favorite, with older paintings plus works for sale. Right off the main street in Ubud.

high quality traditional balinese art. lots of paintings in the traditional style, many from early in the 20th century. and pleasant grounds in the heart of the busiest part of ubud, and a cafe makes it a welcome refuge.

Balinese History. The Museum Puri Lukisan houses one of the most complete Balinese Collections in 4 separate buildings. Rudolph Bonnet, The Dutch Painter, was one of the founders of this museum and it is steeped in history of Bali with photos to show the progression over the years.

Beautiful Balinese artwork. The ticket price was a little more expensive however it did include a drink and cake as part of the price so I was happy about that! The balinese artwork was beautiful and it was interesting to see the newer exhibition as well. The artwork, buildings and grounds were all very well kept.
Beautiful gardens, relax time!. Liked:The gardens, with the lotus flowers and the relax environment. The art is also nice with more contemporary art.

If you are looking for a real Balinese painting. Pay a visit if you are interesting in painting Balinese style, though they have slight variation of impressionist paintings to choose from. No da Vinci or Michelangelo pieces here, don't get too excited

Informative. On our trip to Ubud we visited the museum. It is easy to find as it located in the middle of the town and near Ubud market. It has three main hall. While it is dedicated to a number of Balinese artists works, we found very informative. It helped to understand the Balinese culture and history. The exhibits were around the village life, mythical creatures and bits and pieces about the history. The museum is one of the best I've visited in Indonesia yet some urgent renovation are needed to attract more visitors .The cafe was good and the ticket included free drinks. I strongly recommend a visit to this museum.

Nice to see some historic art. The place really only has art. We thought it would be a bit more historic and tell the story of Bali and Indonesia a bit more but no. Perhaps that was our mistake for misunderstanding.The art is really nice and you can really tell how the painters have been influenced by religion.It's also interesting to see the painting style which is nothing like western art.Probably great if you are into art or at least quite interested.We thought it was good, however not really what we expected.

Important if you love art. This museum is centrally located down from the Palace and houses some important art, including work by Lempad, who died at the age of 116, and who was creating right up until his death. He helped design the gallery's pavilions. The grounds are beautiful and you could spend hours there. Perfect way to spend a rainy afternoon.

A very quality museum with lovey grounds. These beautiful grounds host some fantastic art. You could spend a day here enjoying the environment- especially if you wanted to sit down and paint a bit- which you would be free to do. Like most museums here you get a free cup of tea or coffee with your ticket- which is always worth the while to sit down and enjoy. I found the art at this museum to be the best overall in Ubud- I felt it was the most rigorous in terms of quality and scope of history. I was really thrilled by the experience and would highly recommend it to even a casual lover of art. It is also just a fun and beautiful space to enjoy Indonesian culture. A lovely oasis in the bustle of Ubud.
Good and interesting. First time in Bali and I didn't know anything about the art history of Bali, visiting this museum was very helpful to learn more about the history and the current art

Solitude and art just off Ubud's Main Street.. Intriguing Balinese art, especially that of the pre-War period. Two hours will allow you to view everything at a relaxed pace, to enjoy the grounds, and savor a nice cup of tea or coffee. Interesting to learn how Balinese art has evolved and incorporated outside influences while remaining true to its cultural roots.
Well worth a visit. Some beautiful works of art here, both pre and post-war. Set is stunning gardens and a lovely café with good coffee. Not to be missed.

Highlight of the trip to Ubud. We wandered into the museum grounds on a whim for dinner and it was magical. The museum is a pretty place to explore by day but by night it was just gorgeous. We found out later that you can buy a combined museum and dinner ticket for R125,000 and the museum is open until 6pm then diners have the grounds to themselves. Lovely restaurant, unbeatable setting. It was a mystery why we had the place virtually all to ourselves. Extremely romantic setting and excellent service.

Another fine museum in Bali. The Puri Lukisan, Neka and Agung Rai are the three major museums in Ubud. Though their collections are similar, they are all worth a visit, both for the paintings (and sculptures) and the beautiful gardens. The Puri Lukisan, close to central Ubud, is particularly pretty - and the complimentary coffee/tea and pastries in the café are a treat.

nice artwork n history of bali. this is a museum that not to be missed in the trip. very nice painting, artworks from history to modern art. take your time to finish all the galleries.they provided types of entrance fees: suggest to take a break with tea or coffee in the museum. enjoy very much.

Beautiful Art, Beautiful Setting. This is the place to go to see some amazing Balinese Art and get a good sense of traditional style. The collection is mostly early 20th century from numerous artists and is housed in three buildings surrounded by park-like gardens. The art itself is very impressive and inspiring and captures so much detail of Balinese life, landscape, and culture. Although it is right in the center of Ubud we nearly had the place to ourselves. The ticket price includes a welcome drink at their cafe where we also had soup delicious soup. Definitely worth checking out.
Excellent!. The work of art displayed here are great. It shows local artists from early 20th century with a little occidental influence in their style. Nicely show and beautiful surroundings.
Excellent survey of Balinese art. Good collection of Balinese art of many schools. Well explained. Free beverage with admission. Outdoor spaces for performances.

Take some time to relax away from the streets.. I really enjoyed the hour or so that I spent wandering through the buildings and the lovely gardens at this museum. Although pretty much in the centre of town there were not many people there, and it was very relaxing to be able to view the artworks at whatever pace you chose without the pressure of other people pushing through. There was good information provided on the works and I found it a good insight into Balinese art both old and new. The coffee house was also a pleasant spot to relax and enjoy the complimentary drink included in the admission price.
Nice museum. Nice museum which gives a genuine idea about Indonesian art. Lovely gardens and a very nice coffeehouse.

Informative. I love visiting museum, and this has became one of my fave. I like history. They put adequate information in each of the painting and picture. They also have adequate information in the brochure. Helpful staff to direct as to visit each of the building. And they also include a complementary drink in the ticket. It was nice after we stayed and enjoy the museum for a couple of hours.

Lovely snapshot of Balinese art. I took my 10 year old daughter as she loves art. It was a beautiful tranquil place tucked in amongst the busyness of Ubud. I didn't have to pay the $5.00 entry fee for my daughter, which I thought was very generous. That included a welcome drink for us both. There were not a lot of people there when we went so we enjoyed wandering and taking photos. A lovely experience.

A quiet, serene oasis. The day I went to the museum there was hardly anyone there, so it was very peaceful and serene. Though the art collections are minimal, they are interesting and diverse. The grounds and gardens are lovely. A man was playing the gamelan outside one of the buildings, which gave me a relaxing chance to sit and listen in the shade - very atmospheric. The café was quite good too and reasonably priced.
Beautiful Art Museum. Lovely terraced grounds. Friendly staff. Free complimentary drink included in entry fee $5. Well worth the visit.

Interesting and extensive museum with pretty grounds. We visited every pavilion and wandered extensively round the grounds. The place was calm and tranquil (maybe we were lucky to be amongst just a few couples visiting that day - pre-high season) and the signs were informative.We both felt we learnt something about Balinese art, ancient and contemporary, as well as Balinese culture in general. No pushy guides and the people at the cafe (cold beverage included in the price of entrance) were also very nice.

offers an authentic experience. visited here in April 2013 during our short trip to Ubud.for a IDR 50K entrance fee this museum is definitely worthed, got myself a refreshing welcome drink beforeward and also equipped with wi-fi connection services.this museum is rather a well maintained buildings with large gardens, each halls represents a different stories/timeline of balinese art. unfortunately our visit here lasted only for 30 mins which was not enough to properly explore the whole facilities..definitely will comeback someday and recommend this for those who likes art (especially paintings) and want a authentic representation of balinese culture.

Fascinating. Excellent museum st in beautiful gardens well worth a stroll around. A small oasis of peace and tranquillity away from the tourist hoards on the streets of Ubud -oh and the taxi drivers touting for business!

A museum worth seeing. For a small fee, we spent a lovely two hours wandering around this museum. We did not see a single other person so it felt as if we had the place to ourselves ~ rather surreal. There is much to see and absorb and the grounds are very grand. Well worth a visit.

Some really groovy, unexpected pieces. I headed for this museum because it was so close to where we staying, and I'm glad I did. The $5 admission fee was well worth it for 3 big houses of paintings and sculptures (and lovely grounds). I'm a little shocked at the heat & humidity in the buildings as far as how these paintings are to be preserved for the longterm, but, I'll let them figure that bit out. The price of admission includes a drink at the cafe at the end--I highly recommend the lime juice ; )

Good collection in the middle of downtown. Nice museum with a variety of paintings and wood sculptures. It's location in the middle of downtown Ubud makes it easy to reach. Its collection tends to the more recent and modern works. Spread over several separate buildings with fountains, pools, and sculptures, makes certain that you don't forget where you are. A nice feature that you should take advantage of is the free drink in the museum cafe: the setting is charming.

Serene art museum with impressive collection. I really enjoyed my visit to this museum. They had an interesting collection of modern and traditional paintings and wood carvings. I wish they had more wood carvings, actually. Entrance fee includes a complimentary drink at the quaint on-site cafe. Helpful staff and beautiful gardens.

you could spend days here!. so much to see! I went her on my first day in Ubud-- what a good idea! so much traditional artwork and paintings, scultpures, gardens, and even workshops to take! bring your sketchbooks and be in artist paradise... then cool off with a complimentary drink at the museum café and admire the absolutely otherwordly surroundings. Artist heaven.
excellent museum. great catalogue of traditional balinese art in a beautiful and central location near the Ubud Palace

Beautiful quietude in the middle of Ubud. The art is good too! We really enjoyed our 9:00 AM visit here. There are 4 large buildings filled with Balinese paintings and carvings. A good introduction to traditional Balinese art.

Valuable and interesting collections in a beautiful `palace'. Although I don't really know how to appreciate traditional Balinese art, I find the paintings and artifacts exhibited in this museum fascinating and eye-opening. Some of the works are dated to hundreds of years and they show the exceptional skills of the artists on top of their creativity and sheer talents. It's one of the best art galleries in Ubud I've seen and worth a visit if arts and culture are your cup of tea.

learn about Balinese art........ I really enjoyed my visit to this museum - I wouldn't have classed Balinese art as my especial favourite but I felt my visit had given me far more appreciation of Balinese culture and their different styles of painting.There are wonderful wood carvings some of which use roots and distorted wood incorporated into the sculture. Other wood carvings a delicate and flowing -There was a collection of paintings on cloth which were most fasciinasting - niave in style and divided into squares representing months, lunar cycles, astrological signs - This collection was donated to the museum by a Dutchwoman (?) - for me it was the most interesting of all but there is enough to see to give you a culture lesson in a couple of hours!!

Don't miss this essence of Bali experience.. Before you purchase any paintings, sculptures or carvings in Bali, this museum will give you a broad overview of the trends, quality and history of the arts in Bali. This was the first museum in Ubud, conveniently located right downtown (used to be surrounded by rice paddies). It has a comprehensive collection, and some wonderful older pieces in a beautiful garden setting. The collections are clustered in multiple pavillions, and walk you through classical, Ubud, Batuan, Sanur and Young Artist developments. There are also nice examples of the evolution of the carving traditions. Unlike the best western museum exhibitions, the captions often leave something to be desired, but the visual instruction is unparalleled. Even if you're not a collector, seeing the range and depth of imagery and styles, as well as the themes in the artwork is an education in itself. The pastoral scenes, by the river and village scenes span the years when Ubud was a tiny village, to now, when tourists with long camera are painted into the temple ceremony pictures. Pure insight into the culture you would otherwise have to read volumes to glean.One carving I admired led me to seek out the artist's studio in Mas. There I was able to meet him, see his other (available) pieces, as well as the catalogues from exhibits where he'd been featured. There is a small bookstore, and the price of admission includes a free beverage. They do offer classes in their open air pavillion, book ahead.

History of Ubud and Balinese Arts. Although the admission is a bit expensive (50,000 IDR/adult) for an Indonesian museum, it's because it's self-managed by a private institution. I find the collections are well-managed, some of them are going through renovation.There's no air-con in the building, so be prepared to suffer in a hot weather. But you can use your ticket to get a free drink in the museum's cafe.It has a number of workshops. Each takes around half a day.The museum has largely a collection of paintings, few are photographs and sculptures. Mostly the paintings depict the legends and daily lives (like farming) of the locals. The information of some artworks is incomplete, and I find the way they arrange the articles is a bit inconsistent. Nevermind this, it's still great if you want to get familiar with Balinese arts.

First Museum in Ubud. I don't know excatly what year it was builded, but I know it was build by the king of Ubud and a Dutch artis named Mr. Rudolf Bonnet,.. great collections of painting and sculptures and some of them anonimous..if you are art lover it will be good to be there..

interesting and instructive. First you have to know that museum is not the same indoor institutian as we know from Europe and everywhere. Museum in Bali is anice and very beautiful park area with some open houselike buildings, small cafe and couple of beautiful buildins with nice paintings on the wall. This museum gives a very good overviews of Balines art. Walking around in Bali you can see that there is a perception of art of every place and person. In this museum will become clear where it comes from.

Workshops. Recently, We enjoyed taking a puppet making and gamelan class here on a very rainy day. Our instructors were warm, talented, informative and genuine. Would recommend to anyone interested in the arts with limited time in Ubud. The price for the workshops were fair. Schedule one day in advance.

interesting and different. there are 3 main buildings housing the permanent collections and special exhibitions from time to time. Grounds are pleasant to walk around. There were some displays which provide an historical perspective on art and infiltration of westerners into Bali art circles, plus some old pieces that help preserve some of the older local artists work. Also small selection of sculptures and carvings. Short on detailed descriptions in parts and good detail elsewhere for English speakers. No audio available. It is not an extensive gallery, unlikely to be very crowded, an hour will give a good look, 2 hours to get into more detail. The offer of a free drink at the cafe that comes with entrance ticket is a nice gesture. Acceptable toilet facilities on site and free.
can give a miss. there is nothing great except a few paintings which yu can see anywhere no need to pay ticket. only thing nice if yu want to have a cup of tea it is nice location in the crowed ubud

Interesting Indonesian Art. Traditional Indonesian Art. Museum located near town center. Free soda included with ticket. They had an area where you could play some of the Indonesian instruments. We arrived around noon and I think there was a jam session of locals playing - quite charming. Helpful guards.

Balinese art. It is a lovely musuem if you like art. It is located in a magnificent garden and is divided into a few sections. The entrance fee is 50,000 rupiah -which can be seen as slightly overpriced but the collection of paintings is impresive, especially modern art. We visited it during a coffee festival which meant the place was full of coffee lovers. You get a free drink with the ticket and we had a chance to see gamelan practice.

Great overview of Balinese art. This art museum is spread over four buildings (including a fairly new one near the entrance steps) and focuses primarily on 20th century and contemporary Balinese art. The most enjoyable aspects for me were in Building I (where the I Gusti Nyoman Lempad collection is together with other earlier art styles less affected by the Western art tradition) and Building III (where wayang style paintings and tapestries are hung). Building II (which contains post-war art) and the new building (which contained a temporary contemporary art exhibition with paintings for sale and a display on the founding of the museum) were also good, but didn't captivate me as much as the other buildings. We were also fortunate enough to see an older man practising a rindik (Balinese gamelan instrument) outside Building I. He enough was nice enough to let me have a play of it!There is a lot to see at the museum and you might need close to 2 hours to do it justice. Admission to Puri Lukisan is Rp 50000 per person and includes a tea, coffee or mineral water at the cafe.During this trip, I also went to the ARMA Museum in Peliatan. If you had to choose between them, I would slightly prefer the ARMA Museum, mainly because the conservation practices are a little better there. Some of the older works in Puri Lukisan are starting to fade, though you can still clearly see the intentions of the artists.

Wonderful Museum and workshops for kids are excellent !!. We have known this Museum for twenty years now and know one of the former directors who always accompanies us there. The Museum Entrance has been rebuilt since we last came (in 2010) and the whole museum has been revamped and cleaned up.The permanent collection is, as always, excellent, fascinating and well presented.There was a new exhibition when we were there with new Balinese artists and historical background which was very interesting and worthwhile.Two children (age 10 and 12) did a painting workshop for a whole morning. The painter who taught the lesson spoke good English, was very talented and friendly and the kids had a great time. They even received traditional treats (fried banana). The price for the workshop is about 10 U$ per hour per kid. Paintre's name is I Wayan Warta Yasa.They also opened a new restaurant there, but we did not eat at the Museum.

A wonderful survey of Balinese art. This museum takes for the studious about 2 hours, for the quick though type, just under an hour. My husband and I took our time. It helped having done a little reading about Balinese art online and in my guide books before going so I had some sort of reference point, because there isn't much interpretive stuff at the museum. However they have an extensive collection of what is considered classical Balinese art and examples from some of Bali's top artists.

For art lovers who know their history of modern Balinese art period. An interesting art gallery heavily focused on the artistic commune that formed between local and overseas collaborators between the 1930s and 60s, it is situated in a large compound that looks to have been recently renovated, and of course, made to look a bit like a temple. The labeling and explanation is a bit hit-and-miss, sometimes providing adequate background info, and other times non-existent, which is weird considering how modern the whole place looks. Some quite old pieces exist, though really the art is a modern take on traditional Balinese design and themes, influenced by western sensibilities and containing an insane amount of detail. Art classes exist, though you need to prebook. The cafe on site has a nice dessert menu, and your ticket entitles you to one free drink.

Fabulous art in a lovely setting. The works on show here really highlight how little true art is being created and sold in Ubud, supposedly the cultural centre of Bali. I would have liked to have spent hours more here investigating the insane detail of the traditional paintings. The gardens are great too, and you get a free cold drink with the price of entry. Highly recommended especially if you intend to buy some art while you're there. Don't go shopping in the local "fine art" galleries and artists' cooperatives with their formulaic abstracts and talentless exotica until you've seen how good Balinese art can be.

Well worth a stop. Wo derail open air garden setting for some excellent artworks. We liked the history of Ubud artists and were especially taken with the works of I Gusti Nyoman who started drawing in his 60s and lived to 116!!

small museum with nice wood work.. Do not expect a big museum,it is small but nice if you are interested in balinese wood work .I had feeling that it is more like an art gallery than museum to be honest.More on sale than display.It is In a very central location if you have 45 minutes to spare.why not?has nice gardens and a cafe.

A brilliant cultural experience. Our family of 2 adults and 3 children divided in two groups and tried mask painting and basket weaving. The 75000rp covered all our materials and morning tea and our teachers were very generous with their time. The allocated 3 hours turned into 5 because of our dedication! and we were grateful for their patience. The teacher taking the mask painting spoke no English and this was no problem even for our 9 year old who was happy to follow the steps. Nyomen was our basket weaving teacher and she spoke English well enough to teach us some Bahasa. Our 11 year old son had no problem following her directions although I think a much younger child would struggle.The best part was coming away from an experience where we had totally immersed ourselves in something different and each had a sense of accomplishment as we took our own souvenirs away along with the memory of just being there.The setting was beautiful. We each worked in a traditional pavilion among the museum grounds where it was quiet and just a delight to feel removed from the hustle of touristy Ubud. If you are looking for something a bit different and have the patience to sit and try something new then I would thoroughly recommend it. The museum also has batik painting, balinese dance and gamelon instruction.They also have a restaurant and lovely clean toilet facilities.

Must see!. This is one of the best museums I've ever seen (next to the Museo de Oro in Bogota). The grounds are beautifully landscaped for the small fee you pay (fee includes a free drink). The art features many Hindu, surrealist and landscaped art works. The Batik paintings in particular are so 3-D you can almost jump in. Great way to spend 2 hours.
Very ancient & informative. Had seen many temples at this stage, so not very impressed

Good value art/craft classes. The Museum offers a range of classes from mask painting, woodcarving, offering making to Batik and traditional Balinese painting. I did the painting class, which was Rp350,000 for the day. I sat with an artist who showed me some sketches and for a start I thought I’d be doing something like ‘paint by numbers’, but I was pleasantly surprised. Once my choice was made, 2 clean sheets of paper were produced and I then spent the day learning how to sketch, outline, shade and paint using layer upon layer of color. The artist was very patient, showing me ‘step by step’ as he put it. If I needed help, he gave it. I was the only student, but he does take up to 4 people in the busy season. As well as the class drinks, snacks and a delicious lunch were included.

One of Ubud's major art museums. Entry is Rs 50,000 which includes a complimentary drink. This art museum is in the heart of Ubud and well worth a visit. There are excellent gallery spaces in a beautiful garden. Be sure to also visit Neka Art Museum (different from Neka Gallery) and Agung Rai Museum of Art (ARMA).

The real museum of Ubud. The single most important museum in Ubud, master minded by Rudulph Bonnet and the former King/Crown Prince. The museum holds a vast collection of the most important local artists, and the setting is outstanding.
